openings.title: Caro-Kann Defence
openings.description: A solid reply to 1.e4. Black fights for the centre with pawns on c6 and d5, keeping a sound pawn structure and developing the light-squared bishop outside the pawn chain.

moves.comment: White opens with the King's pawn, controlling the centre.
The Caro-Kann! Preparing to challenge the centre with ...d5 next move.
White claims more central space with both pawns.
Black strikes at e4 immediately. The point of 1...c6 — the d5-pawn is supported.
White defends the e4-pawn with the knight — the Classical Variation.
Black captures, opening the diagonal for the light-squared bishop.
White recaptures with the knight, centralising it powerfully.
The signature move! Developing the bishop outside the pawn chain before playing ...e6.
White attacks the bishop, forcing it to decide where to go.
The bishop retreats to a safe diagonal, still active outside the pawn chain.
An aggressive pawn thrust, threatening h5 to trap or trade the bishop.
Preventing h5 for now, giving the bishop a retreat square on h7.
White develops the knight to its natural square, preparing to castle.
Developing the knight to d7 rather than c6, keeping the c-file open and supporting ...e6.
White pushes the h-pawn, displacing the bishop from the g6 diagonal.
The bishop retreats to h7. It looks passive but remains useful after ...Bd3 trades.
White develops the bishop and offers a trade of light-squared bishops.
Black trades bishops. This is fine — White's light-squared bishop was more active.
White recaptures with the queen, centralising it.
Black solidifies the centre and opens the dark-squared bishop's diagonal. A model Caro-Kann position.

openings.title: Ruy Lopez
openings.description: One of the oldest and most classical openings. White develops quickly, pins the knight defending e5, and builds long-term pressure. The Closed Morphy Defence is the main line.

moves.comment: King's pawn — claiming the centre and opening lines for the bishop and queen.
Black mirrors, fighting for central control.
Developing the knight and attacking the e5-pawn.
Black defends e5 with the knight.
The Ruy Lopez! The bishop pins the knight that defends e5, creating long-term pressure.
The Morphy Defence — Black asks the bishop to declare its intentions.
Retreating but maintaining the pin. White keeps the tension.
Black develops and counterattacks the e4-pawn.
Castling early! The king is safe, and the rook eyes the e-file.
Black develops the bishop modestly, preparing to castle.
The rook supports the e4-pawn and controls the open e-file.
Black gains space on the queenside and forces the bishop to retreat.
The bishop retreats to a strong diagonal, aiming at f7.
Black supports the e5-pawn and opens a path for the bishop.
Preparing d4 to challenge Black's centre. A key Ruy Lopez idea.
Black castles, getting the king to safety.
A useful prophylactic move — preventing ...Bg4 pinning the knight.
Black reroutes the knight to pressure the b3-bishop.
The bishop retreats to safety, still eyeing the kingside. A typical Ruy Lopez manoeuvre.
Black strikes at the centre. The Closed Ruy Lopez — a rich middlegame ahead.

openings.title: Italian Game
openings.description: One of the oldest openings in chess. White develops the bishop to c4, targeting the vulnerable f7 square, then builds a strong pawn centre with c3 and d4. The Giuoco Piano is the main line.

moves.comment: King's pawn — claiming the centre and opening lines for the bishop.
Black mirrors, fighting for central control.
Developing the knight and attacking the e5-pawn.
Black defends e5 with the knight.
The Italian Game! The bishop targets the vulnerable f7 square.
The Giuoco Piano — Black mirrors with an active bishop, also eyeing f2.
Preparing d4 to build a strong pawn centre. A key Italian Game idea.
Black develops the knight and counterattacks the e4-pawn.
White strikes in the centre! The whole point of 4. c3.
Black captures, opening the position.
White recaptures, building an ideal pawn centre on d4 and e4.
Black checks the king, disrupting White's development.
Blocking the check with the bishop — the simplest response.
Black trades bishops. The capture gives check since d2 is diagonal to e1.
The b1-knight recaptures, keeping the f3-knight active for the centre.
Black strikes back in the centre, challenging White's pawn duo.
White captures, opening the e-file.
Black recaptures with the knight, centralising it powerfully on d5.
White castles, getting the king to safety and connecting the rooks.
Black castles too. An open, dynamic middlegame lies ahead.

openings.title: Sicilian Defence — Najdorf Variation
openings.description: The most popular defence against 1.e4 at the highest level. Black breaks symmetry with 1...c5, fighting for the centre while creating sharp, imbalanced positions. The Najdorf is the sharpest and most ambitious Sicilian.

moves.comment: White opens with the King's pawn.
The Sicilian! Black fights for the d4 square without mirroring White.
White develops the knight and prepares d4.
Supporting the e5 square and preparing ...Nf6. The most flexible move.
White opens the centre — the Open Sicilian begins.
Black captures, creating the asymmetric pawn structure that defines the Sicilian.
White recaptures with the knight, centralising it powerfully.
Black develops and attacks the e4-pawn.
White defends e4 and develops the knight.
The Najdorf! A flexible move controlling b5 and preparing ...e5 or ...b5.
White develops calmly — the classical approach against the Najdorf.
Black seizes space in the centre and pushes the knight away.
The knight retreats to b3, still influencing d4 and c5.
Black develops the bishop, preparing to castle.
White castles, getting the king to safety.
Black castles too. Both kings are safe.
White develops the last minor piece, eyeing the a7–g1 diagonal.
Black develops the bishop actively, connecting it with the d5 square.
Solid support for e4 and preparing a potential kingside expansion.
Black develops the last piece. A classic Najdorf position — rich middlegame ahead.

openings.title: Queen's Gambit Declined
openings.description: White's most classical opening with 1.d4. The c4 pawn offers a gambit to lure Black's d-pawn from the centre. The Queen's Gambit Declined is Black's most solid and reliable response.

moves.comment: Queen's pawn — claiming the centre and opening a path for the bishop.
Black occupies the centre symmetrically.
The Queen's Gambit! Offering a pawn to deflect Black's d5-pawn from the centre.
The Queen's Gambit Declined — Black holds the centre solidly with pawns.
Developing the knight and increasing pressure on d5.
Black develops and adds another defender to d5.
Pinning the knight to the queen — a key QGD move. The bishop pressures d5 indirectly.
Black develops and breaks the pin, preparing to castle.
Solidifying the d4-pawn and opening the diagonal for the f1-bishop.
Black castles, getting the king to safety.
White develops the knight to its best square.
Black develops the knight, preparing ...c6 or ...dxc4 followed by ...c5.
The rook eyes the c-file, anticipating it opening after ...dxc4.
Black reinforces d5 and prepares the freeing break ...dxc4 followed by ...b5.
Developing the bishop to an active diagonal, eyeing the kingside.
Black releases the tension, capturing the c4-pawn.
White recaptures — the bishop lands on an excellent diagonal targeting f7.
The knight centralises on d5, attacking both the Bg5 and Nc3.
White trades the bishop before Black can play ...Nxc3, keeping the position clean.
Black recaptures with the queen. The Capablanca Variation — a rich strategic battle ahead.
